title: Financial Transaction Networks, Money Laundering Detection, Fraud Patterns - Evidence Sheet

key_findings.title: Extreme Class Imbalance is Fundamental
key_findings.implication: All effective models require explicit imbalance handling; naive models achieve 100% false negatives

key_findings.title: High Accuracy Does Not Guarantee Real-World Effectiveness
key_findings.implication: Evaluation must include temporal holdout and realistic negative sampling

key_findings.title: Isolation Forest Baseline Highly Competitive
key_findings.key_metric: IF: 0.85-0.95 accuracy, 0.70-0.92 F1 (unsupervised, O(n log n))
key_findings.implication: Minimum labeled data requirement - Isolation Forest should be primary baseline

key_findings.title: Graph Structure Provides 2-10% Performance Gain
key_findings.key_metric: GCN: 0.60-0.75 F1, TGN superior AUC vs static GNN
key_findings.implication: Network-aware methods essential for transaction-level fraud detection

key_findings.title: Temporal Dynamics Critical for Money Laundering
key_findings.key_metric: TGN significantly outperforms static GNN; 5-20% degradation with temporal leakage

key_findings.title: Synthetic Datasets Enable Complete Ground Truth
key_findings.key_metric: eMoney and SAML-D: complete labels vs real data with undetected laundering
key_findings.implication: Synthetic data valuable for algorithm development; multi-dataset evaluation recommended

key_findings.title: False Positive Rates Dominate Operational Costs
key_findings.implication: FPR optimization critical; cost-benefit analysis drives practical deployment

key_findings.title: Banking Networks Extremely Sparse and Large
key_findings.implication: Distributed/streaming methods required; full-graph GPU inference infeasible

key_findings.title: Downsampling Most Effective for Large Data
key_findings.key_metric: IEEE-CIS: +0.5% AUC lift from 0.92 to 0.97 with stratified downsampling
key_findings.implication: Preferred over SMOTE for >100K samples; avoids synthetic correlations

key_findings.title: Graph Autoencoders Effective for Unsupervised Detection
key_findings.key_metric: LG-VGAE: +3.7% precision, +7.0% recall, +5.7% F1 over RF baseline
key_findings.implication: Unsupervised representation learning captures latent patterns without labels

key_findings.title: Ensemble Methods Achieve Highest Accuracy
key_findings.implication: State-of-the-art for supervised settings; multiple learners capture diverse patterns

key_findings.title: 28+ Distinct Money Laundering Typologies Identified
key_findings.key_metric: Placement, Layering, Integration phases; SAML-D dataset covers 28 typologies
key_findings.implication: Single-class anomaly detection insufficient; multi-class framework needed

known_pitfalls: Class imbalance severely biases models toward majority class; requires downsampling/SMOTE/cost-weighting
High accuracy (99%+) misleading for fraud detection; false positive rates remain 10-98% in production
Synthetic AML datasets may not capture all real-world complexities; validation against real data essential
Temporal data leakage: models trained on future data perform much better; strict temporal splits required
GNN hyperparameter tuning critical; no universal embedding dimension across datasets
Isolation Forest performance degrades on sparse features and high dimensionality
SMOTE introduces synthetic correlations; apply only to training set, not validation
Cross-border transactions legitimately trigger false positives; geographic stratification needed
Money laundering patterns evolve; models degrade with concept drift (weeks-months timescale)
Real AML data has incomplete labels; undetected laundering mislabeled as legitimate
Graph density matters: sparse networks (0.00014%) create GPU inference challenges
Threshold selection requires precision-recall analysis, not just ROC-AUC optimization
GNN computational overhead prevents real-time inference on 1M+ node networks without optimization
Regulatory explainability requirements conflict with black-box ensemble/DL methods
False positive handling ($274B annually) dominates compliance budgets
Small sample instability: performance varies with test composition and random seeds
Baseline comparison fairness: different papers use different class imbalance treatments
Subgraph sampling biases toward high-degree nodes; representative sampling strategy critical
Transaction amount features may leak label information if not carefully handled
Heterogeneous graph methods sensitive to node/edge type schema design

saml_d_synthetic.coverage: Geographic regions, high-risk countries, payment types

random_forest.limitation: Biased toward majority class without mitigation

graph_autoencoder.advantage: No labeled data required, latent representation learning

smote.risks: Synthetic correlations, overfitting if applied to test
smote.recommendation: Apply to training set only, 1-5% fraud rate

research_opportunities.opportunity: Empirical comparison of synthetic vs real detection performance
Longitudinal studies of pattern evolution; continual learning frameworks
Distributed GNN inference; streaming anomaly detection
SHAP/LIME for GNNs; rule extraction from neural networks
FPR-recall tradeoff curves; ensemble voting strategies
Active learning; weak supervision; self-supervised pre-training
UTXO-aware detection; mixing pool detection; address clustering
Subgraph anomaly detection; community detection for illicit rings
Online GNN algorithms; edge computing for AML

recommendations_for_practitioners: Start with Isolation Forest as baseline (unsupervised, O(n log n), no tuning)
Add XGBoost with scale_pos_weight for supervised setting
Use stratified K-fold cross-validation with temporal holdout
Optimize for precision-recall, not accuracy alone
Implement ensemble voting (2/3 or 3/5 agreement) to reduce false positives
For graph data: start with GCN, add TGN if temporal dynamics important
Retrain models quarterly to combat concept drift
Use SHAP for model explainability and regulatory compliance
Plan for 10-20x higher false positive rates in production than test-set metrics
Validate on held-out temporal data (last 2-4 weeks, no future leakage)
notes: Evidence sheet synthesizing 50+ peer-reviewed papers (2020-2025) on financial transaction networks, money laundering detection, and fraud patterns. Key insights: (1) Class imbalance fundamental (0.17%-3.49% fraud); (2) High accuracy misleading (99%+ test vs 10-98% real-world FPR); (3) Graph methods provide 2-10% gains; (4) Temporal modeling essential for multi-stage AML; (5) Synthetic datasets enable complete labeling; (6) False positive optimization dominates operational value. Primary datasets: IEEE-CIS (590K, 3.49%), eMoney/SAML-D (synthetic), Elliptic (203K nodes, 2.23%). Critical gaps: scalability to 1M+ networks, concept drift, explainability, cross-domain transfer, real-time inference.
